desc.size: Shrub, 3 - 3.5 m tall, 3.5 - 4.5 m wide. Multistemmed with wide-spreading branches.

part.partText: green and hairy when young, becoming gray and less hairy with age.

opposite, nearly stalkless, medium to dark green, 2.5 - 5 cm long, 0.75 - 2.5 cm wide, elliptic to oblong, base tapering or broadly tapering, tip pointed or rounded, margins non-toothed, smooth above, hairy beneath (or only on midrib). Leaves turning reddish brown in autumn.

have both male and female reproductive organs (perfect); on short axillary branches; clustered in a nodding, branched inflorescence; white, small, tubular, petals 4, unpleasant odor. The flower tube is 2 - 3 times as long as the lobes.
a berry-like drupe; in clusters on short axillary branches; black to bluish black, slightly waxy, 6.5 mm long, spherical.

similarSpecies.comments: Without flowers, this species can be difficult to distinguish from Ligustrum vulgare. The flower tube is 2 - 3 times as long as the lobes; on L. vulgare the flower tube is equal to or shorter than the lobes. In general, L. obtusifolium has more blunt-tipped and oblong, nearly stalkless, leaves than L. vulgare.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Occasionally escapes from cultivation and may be found in thickets, fields, woodland edges, disturbed sites, and along waterways.

notes.comments: Introduced from Asia and cultivated in the Chicago Region.

etymology.comments: Ligustrum is the Latin word for privet. Obtusifolium means blunt-leaved.
